comments:
3.2 RC7

The core.jobs package import in the registry manifest is declared as optional but I get an exception when trying to use the registry without it.

- create a new equinox launch config
- select system bundle, common, registry, preferences
- create new plug-in project with an xml file to be used for a dynamic registry contribution (will attach sample)
- start the launch config
- start your bundle

Note that you get the following exception in your console:


osgi> ss

osgi>
Created an attachment (id=44164)
example

Example plug-in to reproduce the problem.

When you start the bundle it tries to make a dynamic contribution to the extension registry. This tries to send out event notification using the Jobs framework, which isn't available.
The EquinoxRegistryStrategy is using Jobs plugin to schedule processing of registry events. 

On the other hand, if you create your own registry strategy (or use RegistryStrategyOSGI or RegistryStrategy), the simplified internal mechanism is used that doesn't require Jobs plugin to be available.

This is why Jobs plugin is marked as optional: you need it for Eclipse registry, but not if you create a registry with one of the pre-canned or a custom RegistryStrategy.

We discussed making registry totally independent from Jobs by always using the "simplified" scheduling mechanism, but run out of time on this for 3.2.

While this works as expected for 3.2, I am setting target milestone to 3.3 as a reminder that this would be a nice improvement to implement.
What is the status of this bug?

I can see that it isn't fixed yet (I tested the 3.3M5 build).

I will provide a patch for this ASAP.
Created an attachment (id=59371)
Patch for jobs optional import

Here is a patch for this. It uses Class.forName() construct to find out whether the jobs import has been satisfied. This has the drawback that the jobs bundle is activated when the registry is activated.

If needed, a different approach can be taken, which will make the check in scheduleChangeEvent() once.

While the patch seems to be straightforward, there are couple issues with this approach.

1) VMs with eager class loading
JVM specification doesn't define when classes are loaded. Some VMs do "eager" class loading - as long as class is specified in imports, it will be loaded. In this case we have "import org.eclipse.core.runtime.jobs.Job" which will case file not found exception on such VMs.

2) Dynamic nature of OSGi
Another interesting point is that Jobs bundle potentially could be added or removed during runtime. I.e., presentnce or absence of Jobs bundle is not a constant.
Created an attachment (id=60444)
Patch

The patch moves ExtensionEventDispatcherJob into a separate class to pacify eagerly loading VMs; some basic handling added to the case of Jobs bundle going away at runtime.

Also, the patch should not cause activation of Jobs bundle which can be an expensive operation in case of the headless startup.

Patch is applied to the CVS Head.
